trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Service Fabric How to monitor and diagnose services locally
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Service Fabric How to monitor and diagnose services locally

trans-unit.source: This article describes how you can monitor and diagnose your services written using Microsoft Azure Service Fabric on a local development machine.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how you can monitor and diagnose your services written using Microsoft Azure Service Fabric on a local development machine.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring and Diagnosing Services in a local machine development setup
trans-unit.target: Monitoring and Diagnosing Services in a local machine development setup

trans-unit.source: Monitoring, detecting, diagnosing and troubleshooting allows for services to continue with minimal disruption to user experience.
trans-unit.target: Monitoring, detecting, diagnosing and troubleshooting allows for services to continue with minimal disruption to user experience.

trans-unit.source: While it is critical in an actual deployed production environment, the efficacy will depend on adopting a similar model during development of services to ensure that it works when you move to a real world setup.
trans-unit.target: While it is critical in an actual deployed production environment, the efficacy will depend on adopting a similar model during development of services to ensure that it works when you move to a real world setup.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric makes it easy for service developers to implement diagnostics that can seamlessly work across single machine local development and real world production cluster setups.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric makes it easy for service developers to implement diagnostics that can seamlessly work across single machine local development and real world production cluster setups.

trans-unit.source: Tracing and logging
trans-unit.target: Tracing and logging

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Event Tracing for Windows</linkText><title></title></link> (ETW) is the recommended technology for tracing messages in Service Fabric.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Event Tracing for Windows</linkText><title></title></link> (ETW) is the recommended technology for tracing messages in Service Fabric.

trans-unit.source: Reasons for this are:
trans-unit.target: Reasons for this are:

trans-unit.source: ETW is fast.
trans-unit.target: ETW is fast.

trans-unit.source: It was built as a tracing technology that has a minimal impact on your code execution times.
trans-unit.target: It was built as a tracing technology that has a minimal impact on your code execution times.

trans-unit.source: ETW tracing works seamlessly across local development environments and also real world cluster setups.
trans-unit.target: ETW tracing works seamlessly across local development environments and also real world cluster setups.

trans-unit.source: This means you don't have to rewrite your tracing code when you are ready to deploy your code to a real cluster.
trans-unit.target: This means you don't have to rewrite your tracing code when you are ready to deploy your code to a real cluster.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric system code also uses ETW for internal tracing.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric system code also uses ETW for internal tracing.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to view your application traces interleaved with Service Fabric system traces, making it easier to understand the and sequences and interrelationships between your application code and events in the underlying system.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to view your application traces interleaved with Service Fabric system traces, making it easier to understand the and sequences and interrelationships between your application code and events in the underlying system.

trans-unit.source: There is built-in support in Service Fabric Visual Studio tools to view ETW events.
trans-unit.target: There is built-in support in Service Fabric Visual Studio tools to view ETW events.

trans-unit.source: View Service Fabric system events in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: View Service Fabric system events in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric emits ETW events to help application developers understand what is happening in the platform.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric emits ETW events to help application developers understand what is happening in the platform.

trans-unit.source: To view these events follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To view these events follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: You must have the following pre-requisties installed.
trans-unit.target: You must have the following pre-requisties installed.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric SDK
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric SDK

trans-unit.source: Launch Visual Studio as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: Launch Visual Studio as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: Create (or open an existing) project for a stateful or stateless Actor or Service.
trans-unit.target: Create (or open an existing) project for a stateful or stateless Actor or Service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a Service Fabric Application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a Service Fabric Application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a Service Fabric Service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a Service Fabric Service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to debug the application.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to debug the application.

trans-unit.source: The Service Fabric events should show up in the Diagnostics Events window.
trans-unit.target: The Service Fabric events should show up in the Diagnostics Events window.

trans-unit.source: Each event has standard metadata information which tells you the node, application and service the event is coming from.
trans-unit.target: Each event has standard metadata information which tells you the node, application and service the event is coming from.

trans-unit.source: You can also filter the list of events using the "Filter events" box at the top of the windows, for example you can filter on Node Name or Service Name.
trans-unit.target: You can also filter the list of events using the "Filter events" box at the top of the windows, for example you can filter on Node Name or Service Name.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Visual Studio Diagnostics Events Viewer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Visual Studio Diagnostics Events Viewer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If the Diagnostics Events window does not automatically show, Go to Server Explorer tab in Visual Studio, right-click the Service Fabric cluster and choose "View Diagnostic Events" in the context menu.
trans-unit.target: If the Diagnostics Events window does not automatically show, Go to Server Explorer tab in Visual Studio, right-click the Service Fabric cluster and choose "View Diagnostic Events" in the context menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open the Visual Studio Diagnostics Events Viewer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open the Visual Studio Diagnostics Events Viewer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add your own custom traces to the application code
trans-unit.target: Add your own custom traces to the application code

trans-unit.source: The Service Fabric Visual Studio project templates contain sample code.
trans-unit.target: The Service Fabric Visual Studio project templates contain sample code.

trans-unit.source: The code shows how to add custom application code ETW traces which show up in the Visual Studio ETW viewer alongside system traces from Service Fabric.
trans-unit.target: The code shows how to add custom application code ETW traces which show up in the Visual Studio ETW viewer alongside system traces from Service Fabric.

trans-unit.source: The advantage of this method is that metadata is automatically added to traces, and the Visual Studio Diagnostic Viewer is already configured to display them.
trans-unit.target: The advantage of this method is that metadata is automatically added to traces, and the Visual Studio Diagnostic Viewer is already configured to display them.

trans-unit.source: For projects created from the service templates (stateless or stateful):
trans-unit.target: For projects created from the service templates (stateless or stateful):

trans-unit.source: Open the Service.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Open the Service.cs file.

trans-unit.source: The call to ServiceEventSource.Current.Message in the RunAsync method shows an example of a custom ETW trace from the application code.
trans-unit.target: The call to ServiceEventSource.Current.Message in the RunAsync method shows an example of a custom ETW trace from the application code.

trans-unit.source: In the ServiceEventSource.cs file, the overloads of the ServiceEventSource.Message method show an option of how to write custom ETW traces.
trans-unit.target: In the ServiceEventSource.cs file, the overloads of the ServiceEventSource.Message method show an option of how to write custom ETW traces.

trans-unit.source: For projects created from the actor templates (stateless or stateful):
trans-unit.target: For projects created from the actor templates (stateless or stateful):

trans-unit.source: Open the "ProjectName".cs file where ProjectName is the name you chose for your Visual Studio project.
trans-unit.target: Open the "ProjectName".cs file where ProjectName is the name you chose for your Visual Studio project.

trans-unit.source: Find the code ActorEventSource.Current.ActorMessage(this, "Doing Work"); in the DoWorkAsync method.
trans-unit.target: Find the code ActorEventSource.Current.ActorMessage(this, "Doing Work"); in the DoWorkAsync method.

trans-unit.source: This is an example of a custom ETW trace from application code.
trans-unit.target: This is an example of a custom ETW trace from application code.

trans-unit.source: In file ActorEventSource.cs, the overloads for the ActorEventSource.ActorMessage method show an option of how to write custom ETW traces.
trans-unit.target: In file ActorEventSource.cs, the overloads for the ActorEventSource.ActorMessage method show an option of how to write custom ETW traces.

trans-unit.source: After adding custom ETW tracing to your service code, you can build, deploy, and run the application again to see your event(s) in the Diagnostic Viewer.
trans-unit.target: After adding custom ETW tracing to your service code, you can build, deploy, and run the application again to see your event(s) in the Diagnostic Viewer.

trans-unit.source: If you debug the application with F5, the Diagnostic Viewer will open automatically.
trans-unit.target: If you debug the application with F5, the Diagnostic Viewer will open automatically.

trans-unit.source: Coming soon
trans-unit.target: Coming soon

trans-unit.source: The same tracing code that you added to your application above for local diagnostics will work with tools that you can use to view these events when running the same code on an Azure cluster.
trans-unit.target: The same tracing code that you added to your application above for local diagnostics will work with tools that you can use to view these events when running the same code on an Azure cluster.

trans-unit.source: Details for this are coming soon.
trans-unit.target: Details for this are coming soon.
